review_title: COVID-19 and lack of CEO, Mr. Gilbert, support

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Perris, CA
pros:
*decent pay if 15$ and hour as a pharmacy tech 
*you get a lot of experience in multiple different fields
cons:
*horrible management 
*they expect you to know something only after 3 days of training and when you mess up they blame you because you should be able to “adapt”.
*super toxic co workers who talk behind your back and judge you when something isn’t done right when literally everyone trains differently there.
*everyone trains different 
*they leave you alone on one shift after limited training
*only per diem and full-time , don’t take per diem it’ll ruin you.
* they tell “you should’ve “ know this or you “you should’ve “ know that and blame you for when anything goes wrong .
*they always take the pharmacist side
*the management always has an attitude 
*management tried to tell you how to do your job
*they get angry when you ask questions 
*they don’t care about the well being of their employees 
*they tell you that you’ll be doing one thing and you’ll do another . I was told I would be trained in outpatient and inpatient and when my hours got cut back as per diem I ask to be moved down to inpatient but they went ahead and hired more people for inpatient and told me no.

review_title: Wish they had more help for the Nurses
job_title: Staff Floor Registered Nurse in Colton, CA
pros: Large county facility, has new everything!  Good for students and new nurses. Computerized charting and a lot of new equipment. Great working experience but for short term, not a good long term place to work. Money is pretty good for per diem RN's Low for staff RN's but raises go up quick.
cons: NO HELP, Nurses must draw their own labs if they are stat. Transportation never available to take patients anywhere, Too many cliques are races among the nurses. Charting is tedious, Call system goes straight to the phone, Unit clerks do not filter call through to nurses making it a very busy phone to answer in the middle of taking care of patients. Needs more organization. Working on a rotation sucks ass! Morale is low on most units, nurses are treated as workhorses more than professionals. CNA mostly hide and do not help unless you get a good one which is rare.

pros: Level 2 trauma, lots of experience
cons: Low pay, low morale, dangerous working conditions. You are forced to leave your other patients to transport your other patient to X-ray, surgery, MRI  and other procedures. Nurses are only "supposed" to draw stat labs, but end up doing phlebotomy's job 80% of the time! even if a phlebotomist is on the floor they'll tell you, "I won't draw your STAT labs", what are they there for? Nurses do their job, plus lab, transport, and lazy CNA work, and are run over and disrespected. Arrowhead is opening the nurses up for lawsuits and dangerous working conditions. Apparently the 1st strike didn't work, since ER is down 40 nurses, ICU 15 nurses, floors are still pooping out nurses. Management does nothing to fix the clear and apparent problems, and creates a further hostile work environment. They'll even create more busy work after nurses are run ragged, and attempt to squeeze as much as they can out of you while you're already overworked. Don't let me get started on the ruthless nursing supervisors, trust me look elsewhere and save yourself the stress.

pros: Knowledge of medical care, insurance process. Helping people in need
cons: Unfair management. No real union, an"association" that lets management do what they want to its employees. Over work employees, they show extreme  favoritism to employees, and no respect towards hard working employees. They state that there's budget cuts but the new CEO has made changes to improve the executive areas. Also their human resources department, has allowed payroll tampering. Employees working overtime with approval and short paying or not paying the overtime. So many issues.

review_title: Management can oftentimes be disorganized. However, the work provides a good challenge and is rewarding.

cons: Management slow to respond to requests, hourly pay lower than the great majority of hospitals, and workload is often pretty heavy.

review_title: One of the most racists workplace in the region

cons: Due to the hospital being a non-profit organization, the rate of pay sucked even after almost 10yrs of service.

pros: Since the pharmacy served the county, it was a fast pace environment to learn the ins and outs of what it would be like to work with pharmacists and doctors.
cons: The pharmacy had an overwhelming amount of patients and refused to hire on more help. The medication dispensing system was old too, which led to very long delays in patient medication delivery. Communication between the pharmacy and doctors was a constant struggle because orders would get messed up all the time.
